EmailTemplate.textOnly: - - - - Clean Clean false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 Hi Bob, Sure thing, just don’t be surprised if they give you trouble. Just in case they do this may be helpful…. Section 2 of the I-9 form is for the employer or "authorized repetitive" of the employer to sign in the case of a remote hire (such as yours.) Because you are a remote hire, we are asking a notary to act as the authorized representative for MBO because we deem them as a "person of trust" it is completely up to them whether they choose to act in this capacity for us. When they sign and date the document they can sign as a “authorized representative” (if they prefer) for their title and there is no need for any kind of notary stamp. We are not asking them to notarize the form (which does go against CA notary law.) Understandably (and unfortunately) a lot of confusion occurs when we ask a notary to sign and date a form as an authorized representative because they have the “position of trust” that a notary carries (but not to notarize the document or act in an official notary capacity on the document.) It’s like asking an office notary to sign for a package (because you trust them) but not to notarize the document stating they received the package.
